instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.P3V3S5_EN: What is P3V3S5_EN? P3V3S5_EN is a signal that enables the power chip responsible for creating PP3V3_S5 when it is high. Signals with _EN mean that whatever is mentioned before the _EN will be enabled or turned on when the signal is high. .
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
threads.message:
Hi there!

I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>  with Green light but no fan spin. It's measuring 0V  at <SIGNAL>PP18V5_DCIN_FUSE</SIGNAL> 

I'd really appreciate any help!

Thank you!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
threads.message: I'm guessing this has something to do with one wire

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
threads.message: If there is really 0v there it must be a dead fuse,  a short or a bad magsafe board

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
threads.message:
Very strange. it's now showing 16.8v at the fuse now. Could've sworn it was 0v .

But anyway, the issue is still there. Have green light but no fan spin and no boot

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
threads.message: Also, have tested another DC in board with no luck.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> voltage??  PP3V3 present at L7260?? <SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> present at L7220??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
threads.message: Are you using a REAL GENUINE APPLE 85W charger?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuates what looks like between 3v and 12 volts. it goes up and down. 
L7260 fluctuates as well, between 0v and 1v
L7220 is just 0v 

Yes always genuine

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
threads.message: I can try a fake one if that helps

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
threads.message: Resistance between pins 17-18 and 27-28 from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, resistance on <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>........  Report values....

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
threads.message: ohms, not mega ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
threads.message: Resistance to GND on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
threads.message: I suspect an issue around <CHIP>U7201</CHIP>. <SIGNAL>P3V3S5_EN</SIGNAL> pulsing high?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
threads.message:
very impressive dukey doo, you magician! 

Looks like crap there. Looks like burnt pins there too! Shall I just replace it all? 

Thanks!  [ATTACH type="full" width="200px"]21244._xfImport[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
threads.message: Ah, also, pin 6 is 0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
threads.message:
Someone else has already messed with this so it will not be fun, you can tell from the <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP> being soldered on some pins and not on others. And the joints that were created without enough flux. 

If you remove F7040 does <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> still pulse or no?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
threads.message: It's been messed with so nothing can be trusted there. Replace <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> and measure resistors and traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Green light but no fan spin
threads.message: Almost looks like the pads were RIPPED OFF
